I'm now implementing the determined replacements. The updated metadata.json now reflects the new name. I've also systematically updated App.tsx based on the review. I'm focusing on the visual updates for that `App.tsx` section. Based on the provided image, I'm analyzing the dark boxes with green check icons. The Portuguese text offers context, but I'm primarily concerned with how to recreate that distinct checkmark list design. My current priority is translating that visual style into code.


**Translating Style and Text**

I've got the `App.tsx` section identified and the language changed to Spanish. Now, I'm working on replicating the visual style seen in the image. I'm focusing on the green checkmark design and the dark box elements, and translating this into the corresponding JSX in `App.tsx`. I think I'm close to a functional implementation.


**Replicating the Visual Design**

I'm now implementing the list design based on that image. I've focused on the container, which is a dark background. I'm focusing on the green checkmark design. The items are in a dark grey background with rounded corners and light text. I've got the `App.tsx` section identified. I think I'm close to a functional implementation.


**Analyzing Card Layout**

I'm now focusing on the image to refine the visual design of the cards. I've realized the previous design was overly complex. The image clearly shows a vertically stacked card structure, not the two-column grid. I'll switch from the current grid layout to a single-column flex or a single column grid. The dark backgrounds, rounded corners, light text and green checkmarks are the core elements. I'm aiming for a concise implementation.


**Implementing Card Components**

I'm now implementing the item as a stacked card structure. Each item will be a styled `div` using a dark background, rounded corners, padding, and a border. The green checkmark is the main visual element, and the text is light in color.


**Refining Card Elements**

I'm now zeroing in on the individual card components. I'll utilize Tailwind classes: Background (`bg-gray-700` or `bg-gray-800`), rounded corners (`rounded-lg` or `rounded-xl`), padding (`p-4`), and a flex layout with `items-center` and `gap-4`. The checkmark will be emerald-500 and bold. The text color will be white/gray-200. I'll update the `App.tsx` section.


**Adjusting Card Text**

I'm now zeroing in on the text elements within each card. I've been reviewing the image and realized the section header text, such as "Com o Can√ß√µes do Altar voc√™ vai:", is actually white, not the green I had previously set. I'll adjust the header text color, specifically updating "CON M√öSICA CON CRISTO VAS A:" to white to match the image. The code is in the `App.tsx` file. I'll use `text-white` Tailwind class. Sentence casing is now being used for the header text.


**Refining Icon Placement**

I'm now focusing on aligning the checkmark icons with their corresponding text. I'll need to use flexbox or grid within each card to ensure the checkmark is consistently placed to the left of the text. I'll test with padding and margin to refine the spacing for both mobile and desktop screens. I'll use inline styles to match the original style with the new font sizes.



**Revising Benefit Block**

I'm now revising the benefit list to match the provided code block, swapping the original structure with the new flexbox approach for each benefit item. I need to make sure I am placing the correct `App.tsx` container for the benefits section. I will be replacing the card with a vertically stacked layout. The new structure uses a rounded container, flexbox, and inline styles for the SVG. I'll test the output to ensure visual consistency.


**Implementing Checkmark Icons**

I'm now focusing on the checkmark icons within each benefit card to mirror the provided image. I see now that the image displays heavy, standalone checkmarks, no circles. I'll implement these as green and bold, adjusting the `strokeWidth` to `4` for visual weight. I'll keep the dark grey card background using `bg-gray-800` to fit the current theme's gradient background.

I'm now integrating the additional components, including `Accordion`, `SalesNotification`, and the SVG icons. I'm focusing on their implementation within the `App.tsx` file to match the current path. I'm testing the components and ensuring they're responsive. The goal is a seamless visual experience.

It appears to be a React app, but it lacks `react-router-dom`, relying on manual path checking instead. This suggests the standard pixel in `index.html` won't track client-side navigation. I've been analyzing the navigation methods. Full page reloads occur when navigating to the 'thank you' page via `window.location.href`, as indicated in `OneTimeOffer.tsx`. While the base Meta Pixel in `index.html` covers full reloads, it won't automatically trigger `PageView` events for client-side route changes using `window.history.pushState` or `setCurrentPath` updates.
